article_title: Special election a test for GOP strength in District 118
article_text: To continue reading this story, you will need to be a digital subscriber to ExpressNews.com.

article_metadata.description: The special election will pit two prominent South Side Democratic families against each other, as Farias’s son, West San Antonio Chamber of Commerce President Gabe Farias, tangles with Tomas Uresti, brother of state Sen. Carlos Uresti and Bexar County Tax Assessor-Collector Albert Uresti.  The election date has not yet been set by Gov. Greg Abbott, but is widely expected to be in November.  Because Joe Farias chose to resign in the middle of his term, we’re now primed for a political obstacle course that will likely require candidates to go through three elections in four months (if a special-election runoff occurs), and four elections in the span of a year.  [...] Lujan initially considered staying out of the special election to concentrate on the Republican primary next March.  George Antuna ultimately won the GOP nomination that year, and Antuna has nothing but glowing words to offer about Lujan.  Nonetheless, the younger Farias acknowledged the strong possibility that one of the Republican candidates will break out of the special election into a runoff.
article_metadata.author.name: By Gilbert Garcia, Metro Columnist

og.description: The special election will pit two prominent South Side Democratic families against each other, as Farias’s son, West San Antonio Chamber of Commerce President Gabe Farias, tangles with Tomas Uresti, brother of state Sen. Carlos Uresti and Bexar County Tax Assessor-Collector Albert Uresti.  The election date has not yet been set by Gov. Greg Abbott, but is widely expected to be in November.  Because Joe Farias chose to resign in the middle of his term, we’re now primed for a political obstacle course that will likely require candidates to go through three elections in four months (if a special-election runoff occurs), and four elections in the span of a year.  [...] Lujan initially considered staying out of the special election to concentrate on the Republican primary next March.  George Antuna ultimately won the GOP nomination that year, and Antuna has nothing but glowing words to offer about Lujan.  Nonetheless, the younger Farias acknowledged the strong possibility that one of the Republican candidates will break out of the special election into a runoff.
